channel.title: Comments on: Use verbose naming in JavaScript
channel.description: On programming and text editing. Addicted to lisps.

item.title: By: kybernetikos
item.dc:creator: kybernetikos
item.description:
I really dislike 'on' and especially 'off' on emitters, but then again, we want our code to feel familiar to other developers...
'addListener' expresses intent better, but if a developer already knows what 'on' does, that communicates intent even better than 'addListener' where they might have to go 'hmm, does this do the same thing as the "on" function that I know, or something different'.
item.content:encoded:
I really dislike ‘on’ and especially ‘off’ on emitters, but then again, we want our code to feel familiar to other developers…

‘addListener’ expresses intent better, but if a developer already knows what ‘on’ does, that communicates intent even better than ‘addListener’ where they might have to go ‘hmm, does this do the same thing as the “on” function that I know, or something different’.

item.title: By: Agreement
item.dc:creator: Agreement
item.description: I've seen this so many times, so have to agree. Verbosity, ftw.
item.content:encoded: I’ve seen this so many times, so have to agree. Verbosity, ftw.

item.title: By: Donniel Thomas
item.dc:creator: Donniel Thomas
item.description: Good article, and I love how you've conveyed your conclusions, arguments and examples in a short, easy-to-digest post!
item.content:encoded: Good article, and I love how you’ve conveyed your conclusions, arguments and examples in a short, easy-to-digest post!

item.title: By: DimitrisK
item.dc:creator: DimitrisK
item.description: I like it. I do exactly the same. The code get better documented right on site, without having to look all around or pray for some comments explaining what the hell is going in there.
item.content:encoded: I like it. I do exactly the same. The code get better documented right on site, without having to look all around or pray for some comments explaining what the hell is going in there.
